channel.title: Introduction to a simple "if statement"

item.title: Introduction to a simple "if statement"
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

before teaching other people, i'd learn how to do it urself...
if some noob is having trouble il add some more to this tut:

"==" is not the only symbol used in if's
you can also use "<" (less then), and ">" (more then),
"!=" (not equal) and some other stuff im too lazy to post

also to do "double-checks" (what i call them) you can do this:

if(name.equals(otherName) || 5 == 2)
{
}

in this case, it will only do itself (lol) if name is other name OR 5 is 2.

also, you can do

if(name.equals(otherName) && 5 == 2)
{
}

in this case, it will do it if name is othername AND 5 is 2.

JAVA P00NZ YOU PL0X

im java programmer 4 life plx

Read full topic

item.title: Introduction to a simple "if statement"
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

public class hi {
	public static void main(String args[]) {
    	String name = "hello";
	String otherName = "hello";

	if (name == otherName)
		System.out.println("They are equal.");
}
}

item.title: Introduction to a simple "if statement"
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

No one's stopping you from helping...it's great that you wrote this and are trying to help out. But even so, sometimes when writing a tutorial it's necessary to go into a bit more detail to explain certain concepts. I only explained the String comparison so that anyone new to java reading this tutorial won't get confused later about why all strings don't compare with an == sign.

item.title: Introduction to a simple "if statement"
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

To follow up, string comparisons like the one in the example are not technically the correct way to compare the value of two strings. Being that they are both strings in the above example are string literals and both reside in the same memory address, however, the example works as expected.

But it's still preferred to use the equals method instead. So:

if(name.equals(otherName))
    System.out.println("They are equal.");

Read full topic

item.title: Introduction to a simple "if statement"

item.description:
@badboy wrote:

ok open notepad and paste this into it

public class hi {
    public static void main(String args[]) {
    	String name = "hello";

	String otherName = "hello";



	if (name == otherName)

System.out.println("They are equal.");

}
}

then save this as hi.java compile n run.

ok an if statement is when you say "if" something is there or doing something then do this.

e.g

if (name == otherName)
System.out.println("They are equal.");

that means if our String name is set to hello and our String otherName is set to hello then it will print They are Equal have fun edit the vaes of string name and string otherName and the output
